t: Proverbs 25
More Proverbs of Solomon
These*p are more proverbs of Solomon, compiled by the men of Hezekiah king of Judah:
It*pn is the glory of God to conceal a matter; to*ld search out a matter is the glory of kings.
As*ln the heavens are high and the earth is deep, so*ld the hearts of kings are unsearchable.
Remove*pn the dross from the silver, and*ld a silversmith can produce a vessel;
remove*ln wicked officials from the king’s presence, and*ld his throne will be established through righteousness.
Do*pn not exalt yourself in the king’s presence, and*ld do not claim a place among his great men;
it*ln is better for him to say to you, “Come up here,” than*ld for him to humiliate you before his nobles. What*pn you have seen with your eyes
do*ld not bring hastily to court, for*ln what will you do in the end if*ld your neighbor puts you to shame?
If*pn you take your neighbor to court, do*ld not betray another’s confidence,
or*ln the one who hears it may shame you and*ld the charge against you will stand.
Like*pn apples of gold in settings of silver is*ld a ruling rightly given.
Like*ln an earring of gold or an ornament of fine gold is*ld the rebuke of a wise judge to a listening ear.
Like*pn a snow-cooled drink at harvest time is*ld a trustworthy messenger to the one who sends him; he*ld refreshes the spirit of his master.
Like*ln clouds and wind without rain is*ld one who boasts of gifts never given.
Through*pn patience a ruler can be persuaded, and*ld a gentle tongue can break a bone.
If*pn you find honey, eat just enough— too*ld much of it, and you will vomit.
Seldom*ln set foot in your neighbor’s house— too*ld much of you, and they will hate you.
Like*pn a club or a sword or a sharp arrow is*ld one who gives false testimony against a neighbor.
Like*ln a broken tooth or a lame foot is*ld reliance on the unfaithful in a time of trouble.
Like*ln one who takes away a garment on a cold day, or*ld like vinegar poured on a wound, is*ld one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
If*pn your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat; if*ld he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
In*ln doing this, you will heap burning coals on his head, and*ld the Lord*s will reward you.
Like*pn a north wind that brings unexpected rain is*ld a sly tongue—which provokes a horrified look.
Better*pn to live on a corner of the roof than*ld share a house with a quarrelsome wife.
Like*pn cold water to a weary soul is*ld good news from a distant land.
Like*ln a muddied spring or a polluted well are*ld the righteous who give way to the wicked.
It*pn is not good to eat too much honey, nor*ld is it honorable to search out matters that are too deep.
Like*pn a city whose walls are broken through is*ld a person who lacks self-control.
